Dialogue: Il signor Ripley ha una fidanzata, il signor Dickie ha una fidanzata e probabilmente il signor Freddie Miles ha molte fidanzate.

Speaker: verrecchia
Dialogue: Mamma mia, quante fidanzate!

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: He says so many fiances.

Speaker: verrecchia
Dialogue: Lei ha ucciso prima Freddie Miles e dopo Dickie Greenleaf! Vero?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: He wants to know if you killed Freddie Miles and then killed Dickie Greenleaf?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Ask him if he's accusing me!

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: He's already angry, I don't think -

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Just because he doesn't like Americans!

Speaker: verrecchia
Dialogue: Non e questo il luogo per le vostre conversazioni private!

Speaker: verrecchia
Dialogue: Hmm. C'e questa...

Speaker: verrecchia
Dialogue: Questa lettera e stata trovata nell'abitazione del signor Richard Greenleaf a Roma.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: They found this in Dickie's place in Rome.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You opened this?

Speaker: verrecchia
Dialogue: Of course!

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You ask me all these questions and you've already read this suicide note?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Can you imagine, if Dickie did kill Freddie, what must that be like? To wake up every morning, how can you? Just wake up and be a person, drink a coffee...?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Whatever you do, however terrible, however hurtful - it all makes sense, doesn't it? inside your head. You never meet anybody who thinks they're a bad person or that they're cruel.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: But you're still tormented, you must be, you've killed somebody...

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Don't you put the past in a room, in the cellar, and lock the door and just never go in there? Because that's what I do.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Probably. In my case it's probably a whole building.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Then you meet someone special and all you want to do is toss them the key, say open up, step inside, but you can't because it's dark and there are demons and if anybody saw how ugly it was...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That's the music talking. Harder to be bleak if you're playing Knees up Mother Brown.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I keep wanting to do that - fling open the door - let the light in, clean everything out. If I could get a huge eraser and rub everything out...starting with myself...the thing is, Peter, if...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: No key, huh?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Hello Peter, so good to see you.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Hello Marge!

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Tom.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I think we sort of found each other.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: He's not coming till the morning. Evidently his stomach - I don't think the food here is agreeing with him.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I was looking forward to seeing him.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Dickie hasn't killed himself. I'm sure of that. There's a private detective on the case now - a Mr MacCarron - Dickie's father's employing him.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: That's a terrific idea.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: He's American. He's already discovered Dickie cashed checks for $1000 the day before he disappeared.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Is this you?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: No, it's Tom's. Splendid, eh?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Golly. Who's paying for this?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Peter found it for me. I can afford it because it's damp and, and falling down.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: This is spectacular.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That's why Tom wanted you to stay.  It's better than squeezing into my room, and I know how you hate hotels.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: A hotel would've been fine.  We'll have to tell Mr Greenleaf how far his dollar has stretched.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What's funny?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: No, nothing. I'm just thinking about when Tom arrived in Mongi.  And now look at you.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Look at me what?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: To the manner born.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Mr Greenleaf.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Tom. How are you?  You look well.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I'm well, thank you.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Far cry from New York.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Yes it is.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Marge, good morning.  Unusual weather.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Very.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: And you, sir?  Any better?

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Pretty good.  Sticking with hot water.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Where's Mr MacCarron?

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: San Remo. The police are amateurs. Well, my boy, it's come to a pretty pass, hasn't it?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Yes.  What's the detective hoping to find in San Remo?

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: He's being thorough, that's all. I'm learning about my son, Tom, now he's missing. I'm learning a great deal about him. I hope you can fill in some more blanks for me. Marge has been good enough to do that, about Mongibello.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I'll try my best, sir. Obviously I'll do anything to help Dickie.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: This theory, the letter he left for you, the Police think that's a clear indication he was planning on doing something...to himself.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I just don't believe that!

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: You don't want to, dear. I'd like to talk to Tom alone - perhaps this afternoon? Would you mind? Marge, what a man may say to his sweetheart and what he'll admit to another fellow -

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Such as?

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: What a waste of lives and opportunities and -

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: - I'd pay that fellow a hundred dollars right now to shut up!

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: No, Marge doesn't know the half of it.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I think it might hurt her to know.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: And his passport photo? Did you hear? To scratch out your own face like that - can you imagine - the frame of mind you'd have to be in?  I've thought about going to the police but I can't face it. I can't face anything anymore.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I feel guilty. I feel like I pushed him away. I spoke and he heard you.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: The moment someone confronts him he lashes out.  He lashes out. You know, people always say you can't choose your parents, but you can't choose your children.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I was asleep. I must have fallen asleep.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You look ghastly, Tom. Are you okay?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Did Dickie's Dad go?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: He's having an early night.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Poor man.  I think I've broken my strap.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Not guilty.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I'll fix some drinks.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: You walk in Venice!

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Are you okay?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I'm fine.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Do you want me to stick around?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: It's okay.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Or I could come back.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Marge, I'm in the bath. Won't be long.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I found Dickie's rings.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: You've got Dickie's rings.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I can explain.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Dickie promised me he would never take off this ring.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Let me put on some clothes and then we can talk about this.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. I have to tell Mr Greenleaf.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Marge, calm down, you're being hysterical.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: He promised me. I swear I'll never take off this ring until the day -

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Shut up! Shut up!

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Marge?  Where are you going?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I was looking for a needle and thread. I wasn't snooping. I was looking for a needle and thread to mend my bra.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: The scent you're wearing. I bought it for you, not Dickie. The thing about Dickie. So many things. The day he was late back from Rome - I tried to tell you this - he was with another girl. I'm not talking about Meredith, another girl we met in a bar. He couldn't be faithful for five minutes. So when he makes a promise it doesn't mean what it means when you make a promise. Or I do. He has so many realities, Dickie, and he believes them all. He lies. He lies, that's his... half the time he doesn't even realize.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Why do you have Dickie's rings?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I told you. He gave them to me.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Why? When?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I feel as if you haven't heard anything I've been saying to you.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I don't believe you.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: It's all true.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I don't believe a single word you've said.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You're shivering, Marge. Can I hold you? Would you let me hold you?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Oh Peter! Get me out of here.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Tom, are you okay?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You try. You try talking to her.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Tom. Tom! Tell me, what's going on?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I give up.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You can't be angry with her.  She's upset and needs someone to blame. So she blames you.  I'll go home and talk to her.  As for you - either get a safety razor or grow a beard.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Is Mr Greenleaf here?

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: Mr Ripley? I'm Alvin MacCarron.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Marge, there's female intuition, and then there are facts -

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Tom.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Hello, sir.  Marge, you should have waited, didn't Peter tell you I'd come by and pick you up?

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Marge has been telling us about the rings.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You know I feel ridiculous I didn't mention them yesterday - I clean forgot - ridiculous.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: Perhaps you didn't mention them because there's only one conclusion to be drawn.

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: I'm going to take Marge for a little walk, Tom.  Mr MacCarron wants to talk with you.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: We could go down to the bar - no need for you to -

Speaker: herbert greenleaf
Dialogue: No, he should talk to you alone.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I could probably see my bedroom from here. I can see my house. When you see where you live from a distance it's like a dream, isn't it?

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: I don't care for B.S. I don't care to hear it. I don't care to speak it.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: Why do you think Dickie's father sent him to Europe in the first place? Did you know at Princeton Dickie Greenleaf half- killed a boy?

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: At a party. Over some girl. He kicked the kid several times in the head. Put him in the hospital. The boy had a wire fixed in his jaw. The Rome Police didn't think to ask Mr Greenleaf.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: Nor did they think to check whether a Thomas Ripley had ever been a student at Princeton University. I turned up a Tom Ripley who'd been a piano tuner in the music department.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: See - in America we're taught to check a fact before it becomes a fact. We're taught to nose around when a girl drowns herself, find out if that girl was pregnant, find out if Dickie had an embarrassment there.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: Mr Greenleaf appreciates your loyalty. He really does. Marge, she's got a hundred theories, but there are a few things she doesn't know. We hope she never knows.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I hope she never knows.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: Three different people saw Dickie get into Freddie Miles' car. A man who won't identify himself because he was jumping someone else's wife at the time saw Dickie removing license plates from a red sports car. The Police know about this man because he happens to be a Policeman.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: I found these in the basement of Dickie's apartment. They belonged to Freddie's car. Mr Greenleaf has asked me to lose them in the canal this evening.

Speaker: maccarron
Dialogue: Mr Greenleaf also feels there was a silent promise in Dickie's letter to you which he intends to honor. He intends to transfer a good part of Dickie's income from his trust into your name. He doesn't intend to give the Italian police any information about Dickie's past. He's rather hoping you'll feel the same.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I feel I never should have said those things to you the other evening. I was pretty flustered, the rings and - and you looked so, I don't know.

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: What are you going to do now, Tom?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I don't know. Peter has a concert in Athens next month - and he's asked if I want to go along, help out. He says goodbye by the way - he's in rehearsal, otherwise -

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: Why do I think there's never been a Ripley rainy day?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: marge
Dialogue: I know it was you - I know it was you, Tom. I know it was you. I know you killed Dickie. I know it was you.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Oh Marge.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Ask me what I want to change about this moment.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What do you want to change about this moment?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Hello.  What are you up to?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: All kinds of things. Making plans.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Plans - good, plans for tonight or plans for the future?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I don't know. Both. My plan right now is to go up on deck, look at the sunset. Come with me.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You go. I don't want to get dressed yet. Come back though.  Come back.  You know, you look so relaxed, like a completely different person.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Well, that's entirely your fault.  And, if I fall overboard, that'll be your fault too.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: Dickie?  Dickie?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Hello Meredith.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: I was looking at you, your clothes, I wouldn't have known you...

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Well, you've spotted me and so you get the reward.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Just kidding. Are you alone?

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: Hardly. I couldn't be less alone.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Of course.  Aunt Joan.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: And co. A lot of co. Oh, God, I've thought about you so much.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I've thought about you.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: When I thought about you I was mostly hating you. Where've you been hiding?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I haven't been hiding. I've been in Police custody. They've been trying to flush out Freddie's killer.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: You're kidding.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: They're letting me have this vacation. Which is why the get-up. Which is why you haven't heard from me.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: You know, the whole world thinks you killed Freddie? It's terrible.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I know. Look, I can't talk now. Later. Later?

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: So - are you travelling under R?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You know what - I am.

Speaker: meredith
Dialogue: Dickie, are you with Peter Smith- Kingsley?  I bet you are. My aunt thought she saw him.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: How was it?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Good. But I think we should stay in here for the rest of the trip.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Was that Meredith?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Was who Meredith?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Meredith Logue. You were kissing somebody. Looked like Meredith.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Hardly kissing. Kissing off.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Didn't look that way - you know - from a distance.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I lied. To her. She thought she'd seen you.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Why lie?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Dickie and Peter, that's just too good gossip, isn't it?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Or Tom and Peter even.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Well that would be even better gossip.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Really, why?  Sorry, I'm completely lost.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I know. I'm lost, too. I'm going to be stuck in the basement, aren't I, that's my, that's my - terrible and alone and dark - and I've lied about who I am, and where I am, and so nobody can ever find me.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What do you mean lied about who you are?

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: I suppose I always thought - better to be a fake somebody than a real nobody.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What are you talking about - you're not a nobody! That's the last thing you are.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: Peter, I... I...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: And don't forget. I have the key.

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You have the key. Tell me some good things about Tom Ripley. Don't get up. Just tell me some nice things.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Good things about Tom Ripley?  Could take some time!... Tom is talented. Tom is tender... Tom is beautiful...

Speaker: ripley
Dialogue: You're such a liar...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: ...Tom is a mystery...
